replies.bodyText: It is not possible right now. However, It can possibly change. There seems to be no implementation problem.
replies.author: heowc

replies.bodyText:
@trustin
Question: Do you want to remove the armeria.security.ports value instead of the optional value?
replies.author: heowc

replies.bodyText: I tried management.server.port and it doesn't bind to that value. Do you want this property to be an additional binding?
replies.author: heowc

replies.bodyText:
Question: Do you want to remove the armeria.security.ports value instead of the optional value?

Yes, we might want to add it later but not until there's a user request.

I tried management.server.port and it doesn't bind to that value. Do you want this property to be an additional binding?

Yes, please.
replies.author: trustin

replies.bodyText:
Thanks for the reply. 😄
We can apply security by checking management.server.port when using Actuator. However, we're obscure which ports to secure internal/docs, internal/healthcheck, and internal/metrics.  😳
replies.author: heowc

replies.bodyText: That's a good question. Perhaps we could default to all services under /internal/ and make it configurable?
replies.author: trustin

replies.bodyText: I've configured the default port(8001) if armeria.security.enabled is true, and have it protect all services under /internal/ on other ports.
replies.author: heowc

replies.bodyText: Question: I specified the default port, but when the user specified management.server.port I didn't remove the default port. Should I avoid specifying a default port?
replies.author: heowc

replies.bodyText:
I have modified some code. I think I can divide it into the following cases.

armeria.security.enabled = false, -> nothing (not secure)
armeria.security.enabled = true, -> port = 8001 (secure)
armeria.security.enabled = false, management.server.port = 1111 -> port = 1111 (not secure)
armeria.security.enabled = true, management.server.port = 1111 -> port = 1111 (secure)
